isis.stitle: Spanish - Guía para Localización de Fallas del Sistema Eléctrico - 3200, 4200, 4300, 4400, 7300, 7400, 7500, 8500, 8600 - STOPMASTER WEDGE TYPE BRAKE - SERVICE - WEDGE ASSEMBLY

step1.para: Remove wedge assembly from plunger housing by pulling it straight out of the housing ( Figure 23).
Remove cotter pin from wedge shaft ( Figure 24) while holding spring compressed by hand.

figure.caption: Figure 24. 1-1/2 Inch (38.1 mm) Stroke Wedge Assembly

step1.para: Remove wedge spring washer, wedge spring rubber boot and wedge spring retainer ( Figure 25).

figure.caption: Figure 25. 1-3/4 Inch (44.45 mm) Stroke Wedge Assembly

step1.para: Insert a thin-bladed screwdriver between one flat of the wedge head and roller retainer cage. Spread the cage open just far enough to remove the rollers ( Figure 26).

caution.para: Do not attempt to drive the wedge through the rollers and cage or force the rollers through the slightly closed slots of the cage. This will permanently damage the cage.

step1.para: Remove the roller retainer cage by sliding it off the wedge shaft. Do not mix components from 1-1/2 and 1-3/4 inch (38.1 and 44.45 mm) stroke wedge assemblies.

Welded on spider brakes ( Figure 27 and Figure 28) have four-piece dust shields attached to the spider with capscrews and lockwashers. Either one or all of the sections can be removed directly from the brake by removing the capscrews and lockwashers.

figure.caption: Figure 27. RDA Welded on Spider, Bolted on Plunger Housing
Figure 28. RDA Welded on Spider, Bolted on Plunger Housing

step1.para: Most bolted-on spider brakes with two-piece dust shields can be serviced as described in Step 1 after removing wheels, drums and brake shoes. Refer to GROUP 04 - BRAKES in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for brake service.

Bolted-on spider brakes with one-piece dust shields will have to be taken off the vehicle for servicing. To remove dust shield from brake, first cage and remove power units, then remove shield-to-spider capscrews and lockwashers. The shields can be replaced with a one- or two-piece dust shield. To cage power unit, refer to , CAGING AND UNCAGING SPRING BRAKE.

On backing plate-mounted brakes, the backing plate serves as a support for the plunger housing and anchor block as well as a dust shield. For servicing remove complete brake assembly. The complete backing plate will have to be taken off the vehicle by removing the plate-to-spindle flange bolts, nuts and lockwashers. To remove brake assembly refer to GROUP 04 - BRAKES in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

With brake shoes removed, remove guide screws and gaskets from the plunger housing. If brake is automatic adjusting, remove pawl assembly or hollow capscrew, gasket, spring, and adjusting pawl ( Figure 29). Use a small magnet to remove pawl if necessary.

figure.caption: Figure 29. Cross Section of Plunger Housing

step1.para: Pry plunger seals loose and remove anchor (solid) plungers, adjusting plungers, adjusting sleeves (actuator) and adjusting bolt.

Thoroughly inspect and clean all parts including the housing plunger, seal bores and shoe rest pads. DO NOT use solvent to clean any rubber parts (plunger seals or gaskets). Wire brush plunger parts and adjusting bolt threads to remove caked on dirt and corrosion.
Carefully inspect plunger seals and gaskets for tears, cuts or deterioration, and replace if necessary. Also check the angled plunger roller faces for pits, grooves or nicks and replace if necessary.

RD spider-mounted brakes have one adjusting plunger and one anchor (solid) plunger per plunger housing. The anchor plungers are marked on the shoe slot end, "R" for right hand brakes and "L" for left hand brakes. DO NOT mix at reassembly.
Assemble seals on plungers and not in plunger housing first. To assemble seal into housing first will result in lack of sealing of internal plunger housing components.

step2.para: Apply a film of grease to inside surface of seals. Refer to LUBRICATE.
Inspect anchor (solid) plungers for burrs. To protect seal, apply masking tape to slotted end of plunger nose ( Figure 30).

figure.caption: Figure 30. Masking Tape Applied to Plunger Nose

step2.para: Carefully push the double lip seal onto the plunger ( Figure 31), stretching the outer seal lip over the plunger nose end until the inner seal lip is completely in the second plunger groove and the outer seal lip is in the first plunger groove. Remove masking tape. (Brakes employing single grooved plungers and single lip seals should be assembled in the same manner except masking tape is not used.)
Coat all plunger bores with grease. Refer to LUBRICATE.

Anchor (solid) plungers - make sure anchor plungers marked "L" are installed in left hand brake and anchor plungers marked "R" are installed in the right hand brake. Refer to Figure 15and Figure 16 for correct location of anchor plungers in the plunger housings.

(1) Coat entire anchor plunger with grease, packing cavity behind seal, and insert plunger and seal into housing with plunger keyway slot aligned with guide screw hole. Make certain the plunger goes all the way into the plunger bore and seats on bosses at the bottom.

(2) Seat plunger seal in plunger housing using a 1-3/4" wrench socket on spider-mounted brakes or a 1-3/8" socket on backing plate- mounted brakes. Be certain that the socket is centered over the seal retainer to prevent damage to the seal.
(3) Assemble gasket and guide screw into plunger housing ( Figure 32).
Make certain guide screw end enters the plunger keyway slot so plunger can slide freely in housing bore. Tighten guide screws to 15 to 25 ft-lbs. (20.3 to 33.9 N•m) torque.
(1) Lubricate outside and inside surfaces of both the adjusting plunger and adjusting sleeve. Position plunger in the plunger keyway slot with guide hole.
Lubricate the seal and adjusting bolt threads and carefully assemble the seal on the bolt, making sure the seal is not damaged. Grease the adjusting sleeve and thread it into the bolt.
Insert sleeve, bolt, and seal ( Figure 33) into plunger already in housing.

figure.caption: Figure 33. Adjusting Bolt and Sleeve Assembly

caution.para: Adjusting sleeve must bottom on shoulder inside of plunger. If bolt is threaded too far into sleeve, bolt will bottom in plunger and automatic adjuster will not function.

step2.para: Coat pawl with grease and insert into housing.

The original design adjusting pawl has teeth and flats on one end and a chamfered edge on the other end. Newly designed adjusting pawl has a key with a corresponding keyway in the spider ( Figure 34).
(2) Tighten pawl capscrew to 15 to 25 ft-lbs. (20.3 to 33.9 N•m) torque.
(3) Using proper size wrench socket, seat seal into plunger housing.
